contextId.information: To walk with someone is a metaphor for being in a close relationship with him. AT: "Enoch had a close relationship with God" or "Enoch lived in union with God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Enoch walked with God

contextId.information: The writer speaks of God killing people as if God were wiping dirt off a flat surface. AT: "I will destroy mankind ... so that there will not be any people on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will wipe away mankind ... from the surface of the earth

contextId.information: The people doing what is evil is spoken of as if they were food that has become rotten. AT: "was rotten" or "was completely evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: was corrupt

contextId.information: The writer speaks of violence as if it were something that could be put into a container and of the earth as a container. AT: "and there were very many violent people on the earth" or "because it was full of people who did evil things to each other" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and it was filled with violence

contextId.information: How a person behaves is spoken of as if it were a way or road. AT: "had stopped living the way God wanted" or "had behaved in an evil way" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: had corrupted their way

contextId.information: The shedding of blood is a metaphor for killing someone. This means that if a person murders someone, someone else must kill the murderer. However, "blood" is very significant in this passage and should be used in the translation if possible. Translate "sheds blood" with words that indicate a major loss of blood that causes death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Whoever sheds man's blood, by man will his blood be shed

contextId.information: God used these two metaphors to tell Abram about his character and his relationship to Abram. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: shield ... reward

contextId.information: Soldiers use a shield to protect themselves from their enemies. AT: "I will protect you like shield" or "I am your shield to protect you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am your shield

contextId.information: This was not an insult. It may mean that Ishmael would be independent and strong like a wild donkey. AT: "He will be like a wild donkey among men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will be a wild donkey of a man

contextId.information: Walking is a metaphor for living, and "before me" or "in my presence" here is a metaphor for obedience. AT: "Live the way I want you to" or "Obey me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Walk before me

contextId.information: Abraham speaks of destroying people as if it were sweeping dirt with a broom. AT: "destroy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sweep away

contextId.information: This metaphor describes Abraham as a human being, who will die and whose body will turn into to dust and ashes. AT: "only a mortal man" or "as unimportant as dust and ashes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: only dust and ashes

contextId.information: To be pleased with someone is spoken as if "favor" were an object that is found. Also, "sight" is a metonym that represents a person's thoughts or opinions. AT: "You have been pleased with me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Your servant has found favor in your sight

contextId.information: This speaks about giving Lot descendants as if his family were a line that they are making longer. AT: "so that we can bear children who will be our father's descendants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that we may extend our father's line

contextId.information: This speaks about giving Lot descendants as if his family were a line that they are making longer. AT: "so that we can bear children who will be our father's descendants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that we may extend our father's line

contextId.information: Giving money to prove to others that Sarah is innocent is spoken of as if he is placing a cover over an offense so no one can see it. AT: "I am giving this to him, so that those who are with you will know that you have done nothing wrong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It is to cover any offense against you in the eyes of all that are with you

contextId.information: God making Hagar aware of the well is spoken of as if he literally opened her eyes. AT: "God caused Hagar to see" or "God showed her" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God opened her eyes, and she saw

contextId.information: "you will be released from the oath you made to me." Not having to fulfill an oath is spoken of as if the person is free from an object to which he was bound. AT: "you will not have to do what you swore to me that you would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will be free from this oath of mine

contextId.information: Learning something is often spoken of as if it were seeing. AT: "to know" (UDB) or "to determine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to see

contextId.information: To pray silently in one's mind is spoken of as if he were speaking in his heart. The word "heart" refers to his thoughts and his mind. AT: "praying" (UDB) or "praying quietly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: speaking in my heart

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) deciding what to do is spoken of as if the person will physically turn one direction or another. AT: "so that I will know what do" or 2) the servant wants to know if he needs to travel somewhere else. AT: "so that I may continue on my journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: so that I may turn to the right hand, or to the left

contextId.information: This speaks about causing someone to be guilty as if "guilt" were an object that is placed on someone. AT: "you would have caused us to be guilty of taking a man's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you would have brought guilt upon us

contextId.information: Here "they" refers to Judith and Basemath. To make someone sorrowful or miserable is spoken of as if "sorrow" were an object that a person could bring to another person. AT: "They made Isaac and Rebekah sorrowful" or "Isaac and Rebekah were miserable because of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They brought sorrow to Isaac and Rebekah

contextId.information: This speaks about being nearly blind as if the eyes were a lamp and the light has nearly gone out. AT: "he was nearly blind" or "he was almost blind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his eyes were dim

contextId.information: Being cursed or blessed is spoken of as if a curse and a blessing are objects that are placed on a person. AT: "Then because of this, he will curse me and not bless me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will bring a curse upon me and not a blessing

contextId.information: "let your curse be on me, my son." Being cursed is spoken of as if the curse were on object that is placed on the person. AT: "let your father curse me instead of you, my son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My son, let any curse fall on me

contextId.information: Esau's anguish was similar to the taste of something bitter. AT: "he cried loudly" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he cried with a very great and bitter cry

contextId.information: This speaks about a birthright as if it were an object that a person could take away. AT: "He tricked me into giving him the double inheritance that I should receive as firstborn son!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He took ... blessing

contextId.information: No longer being angry is spoken of as if the anger turns to a different direction away from the person. AT: "until he is no longer angry with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until your brother's anger turns away from you

contextId.information: This speaks about blessing someone as if a blessing were an object that a person can give. The abstract noun "the blessing" can be stated as "bless." AT: "May God bless you and your descendants as he blessed Abraham" or "May God give to you and your descendants what he promised to Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: May he give you the blessing of Abraham, to you, and to your descendants after you

contextId.information: God causing Leah to be able to become pregnant is spoken of as if God is opening her womb. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so he opened her womb

contextId.information: Jacob's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire. AT: "Jacob was very angry with Rachel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Jacob's anger burned against Rachel

contextId.information: God rewarding Leah is spoken of as if he were a boss paying wages to someone who works for him. AT: "God has given my due" or "God has rewarded me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: God has given me my wages

contextId.information: God causing Rachel to no longer feel ashamed is spoken of as if "shame" were an object that person could take away from someone else. The abstract noun "shame" can be stated as "ashamed." AT: "God has caused me to no longer feel ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: God has taken away my shame

contextId.information: Laban completely using up the money that he should have given to his daughters is spoken of as if he were a wild beast that ate the money as if it were food. AT: "he completely used up our money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has also completely devoured our money

contextId.information: For Jacob to count Laban's dead animals as a loss from his own flock is spoken of as if it was a burden he would bear on his shoulders. AT: "Instead of counting it a loss from your flock, I counted it as a loss from my flock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Instead, I bore the loss of it

contextId.information: "He was very attracted to her" (UDB). This speaks about Shechem loving Dinah and wanting to be with her as if something were forcing him to come to Dinah. This can be stated in active form. AT: "He wanted very much to be with Dinah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: He was drawn to Dinah

contextId.information: God causing the people of the cities to be afraid of Jacob and his family is spoken of as if panic were an object that fell on the cities. The abstract noun "panic" can be stated as "afraid." AT: "God made the people in the surrounding cities afraid of Jacob and those with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: God made panic to fall on the cities

contextId.information: Here looking up is spoken of as if a person literally lifted up his eyes. Also, the word "behold" is used here to draw the reader's attention to what the men saw.  AT: "They looked up and they suddenly saw a caravan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They lifted up their eyes and looked, and, behold, a caravan

contextId.information: This is a figure of speech referring to hiding Joseph's death. AT: "hide his murder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cover up his blood

contextId.information: Here the childrens' coming to their father is spoke of as "rising up." AT: "came to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: rose up

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of working in the master's house as if it were living in the master's house. Only the most trusted servants were permitted to work in their master's house. AT : "he worked in the house" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He lived in the house

contextId.information: When something is "put under someone's care," it means that the person is responsible for its care and safe-keeping. AT: "he had Joseph care for" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: put under his care

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of the blessing that Yahweh gave as if it were a physical covering put over something. AT: "Yahweh blessed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The blessing of Yahweh was on

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of authority as if it were greatness. AT: "I have more authority in this house than anyone else" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: No one is greater in this house than I am

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents Joseph's power or trust. AT: "put Joseph in charge of" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: gave into Joseph's hand

contextId.information: Here Joseph speaks of Pharaoh releasing the cupbearer from prison as if Pharaoh were causing him to lift up his head. AT: "will release you from prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will lift up your head

contextId.information: This speaks about the years of abundance as if time is something that travels and comes to a place. AT: "there will be seven years in which there will be plenty of food throughout the land of Egypt" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: seven years of great abundance will come throughout all the land of Egypt

contextId.information: This speaks of years as if they are something that travels and comes to a place. AT: "during the good years that will soon happen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: of these good years that are coming

contextId.information: To become afraid is spoken of as if their heart were sinking. Here "hearts" stands for courage. AT: "They became very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]]
contextId.quote: Their hearts sank

contextId.information: This is a request for Reuben to take Joseph with him and to care for him on the journey. AT: "Put me in charge of him" or "Let me take care of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Put him in my hands

contextId.information: Something that a person would never do is spoken of as if it were an object that person wants to put very far from himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Far be it from your servants

contextId.information: Something that a person would never do is spoken of as if it were an object the person wants put far away from him. AT: "It is not like me to do something like that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Far be it from me that I should do so

contextId.information: Something bad happening to a person is spoken of as if "harm" were something that travels and comes to a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: harm comes to him

contextId.information: Joseph advising and helping Pharaoh is spoken of as if Joseph were Pharaoh's father. AT: "he has made me a guide to Pharaoh" or "he has made me the chief adviser to Pharaoh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he has made me a father to Pharaoh

contextId.information: This speaks about "poverty" as if it were a destination. AT: "waste away" or "starve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: come to poverty

contextId.information: The best food that a land produces is spoken of as if it were the fat portion of the land. AT: "you will eat the best food in the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will eat the fat of the land

contextId.information: This speaks about time as if it travels and comes to a place. AT: "When it was almost time for Israel to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When the time approached for Israel to die

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of Israel struggling to to sit up in bed as if he were gathering "strength" as someone gathers actual things. AT: "Israel made a great effort to sit up in bed" or "Israel struggled as he sat up in bed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Israel gathered strength and sat up in bed

contextId.information: Giving Ephraim the greater blessing and making him more important than Manasseh is spoken of as if Israel physically put Ephraim in front of Manasseh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Israel put Ephraim before Manasseh

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Joseph having more honor and authority than his brothers is spoken of as if he were physically above them. AT: "To you, who is greater than your brothers, I give the mountain slope" or 2) Jacob means he is giving more land to Joseph than he is giving to Joseph's brothers. AT: "To you, I give one more ridge than I give your brothers. I give to you the mountain slope" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: To you, as one who is above your brothers, I give to you the mountain slope

contextId.information: God cursing Simeon and Levi is spoken of as if God were cursing their anger and fury. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Lord says, 'I will curse them because of their fierce anger and their cruel fury" or "I, the Lord, will curse them because of their fierce anger and their cruel fury" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: May their anger be cursed, for it was fierce—and their fury, for it was cruel

contextId.information: Jacob speaks about Judah as if he were a lion's cub. Jacob is emphasizing Judah's strength. AT: "Judah is like a young lion" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Judah is a lion's cub

contextId.information: Jacob speaks about Issachar and his descendants as if they are a donkey. This emphasizes that they will work very hard. AT: "The descendants of Issachar will be like a strong donkey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Issachar is a strong donkey

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "lying down between the packs they were carrying" or 2) "lying down between two sheep pens." Either way, Jacob speaks about Issachar's descendants as if they are donkeys that have worked hard and are lying down to rest. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lying down between the sheepfolds

contextId.information: Jacob speaks about Dan and his descendants as if they were snakes. Though a snake is small, it can bring down a rider off his horse. So Dan, though a small tribe, is very dangerous to its enemies. AT: "The descendants of Dan will be like a snake beside the road" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Dan will be a snake beside the road

contextId.information: Jacob speaks about the descendants of Naphtali as if they were a female deer that is free to run. This may emphasize that they will be swift messengers. AT: "The descendants of Naphtali will be like deer set free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Naphtali is a doe let loose

contextId.information: Jacob desires for these blessings to be passed on to even the most important of his descendants. AT: "on the head of the most important of Joseph's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: upon the crown of the head of the prince of his brothers

contextId.information: Here anger is spoken of as if it was something physical that Joseph could hold in his hands. AT: "What if Joseph is actually still angry with us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: What if Joseph holds on to anger against us
